Award.AwardTitle: P2C2: Understanding Mean Patterns, Gradients, Variability and Mechanisms of Early Pliocene Warmth: The Role of Cloud Albedo
Award.AbstractNarration:
Observational evidence collected over the past decade indicates that five to four million years ago, in the early Pliocene epoch, the Earth experienced a warm, temperate climate characterized by reduced equator-to-pole and east-west temperature contrasts. Temperatures in the Arctic were perhaps 15-20°C higher than today, whereas warm, El Niño-like conditions dominated the tropics. This climate state persisted while carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere were close to 350-400ppm, matching the present-day elevated levels. Thus, understanding this past climate state is critical if we are to make confident projections for the future impacts of contemporary climate change. However, comprehensive climate models are currently unable to reproduce this state, and especially the prevailing spatial patterns in ocean temperatures. One of the potential causes of these difficulties is an incomplete representation of cloud physics in those models. In fact, cloud feedbacks and cloud response to rising concentration of greenhouse gases remain the most uncertain and least constrained elements of the climate models. Accordingly, the goal of this project is to investigate the role of clouds in maintaining the climate of the early Pliocene, including the role of cloud albedo (or reflectivity) that determines poleward heat transport in the system.

To address this goal, a team of researchers from Yale University will conduct systematic numerical experiments using a state-of-the-art global climate model (Community Earth System Model, CESM) in which they will modify cloud properties that control albedo in the tropics and beyond. The research team will perform sensitivity experiments and realistic simulations of early Pliocene climate, focusing on the differences in the oceanic mean temperature patterns and gradients between the early Pliocene and present-day climates. They will also study the relationship of the tropical mean state and the El Niño-Southern Oscillation phenomenon (ENSO). The model simulations will be analyzed in close collaboration with paleoceanographers, and new observational data will be integrated in the analysis as they become available, while the modeling results will guide future observational studies. The proposed syntheses of paleoclimate data and modeling results will add to our understanding of the mechanisms driving long-term changes in the climate system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central goal of this research project is to understand climate conditions during the early Pliocene epoch, some 4-5 million years ago, including potential mechanisms that maintained Pliocene warmth, specifically the cloud albedo feedbacks, and the mechanisms of the subsequent cooling. The problem of Pliocene warmth (with global mean temperatures 3-5oC higher than today) is directly relevant to contemporary climate change as Pliocene atmospheric CO2 concentrations were close to 400ppm, similar to present-day values. The evolution of the meridional and zonal temperature gradients in the ocean, including the maintenance of a permanent El Niño-like state (El Padro) in the tropical Pacific during the Pliocene, and their effects on climate are among the key problems considered.

The pronounced zonal (east-west) and meridional (equator to mid-latitudes) gradients in sea surface temperature (SST) are two major variables that define the mean climate of the tropics and surrounding regions in the Pacific Ocean. Previous studies have shown that global cooling over the past 5 million years, since the early Pliocene, was accompanied by the gradual strengthening of these gradients. In the course of this project we found that changes in these SST gradients on geological timescales follow each other very closely, reflecting a tight relationship between the two variables connected by shallow oceanic overturning circulation. This tight relationship posits a fundamental constraint on past climates. Further, we have shown that changes in the zonal and meridional SST gradients are critical for Earth’s climate as they control a range of phenomena from El Niño in the equatorial bands to atmospheric hydrological cycle to the possible formation of deep water in the North Pacific. We have also shown that reduced cloud albedo in the extra-tropics provides a plausible mechanism that controls the meridional and hence the zonal SST gradients. Following these ideas, we have simulated a Pliocene-like climate that is in a very good agreement with the available observational proxies. This Pliocene-like simulation sheds light on the possible differences between past and future hydrological cycles, the mechanisms that could facilitate deep water formation in the North Pacific, and the maintenance of Pliocene warmth (with global mean temperature 3 to 5oC warmer than the present).

This project led to eleven manuscripts so far published in leading scientific journals, including several publications in Nature Geoscience, Science and PNAS. Three more manuscripts are currently under review. Project’s results have been presented at numerous invited seminars at universities in the US and abroad and at several international conferences and workshops, including the Pliocene climate workshop in Barcelona (2014), CLIVAR ENSO meetings in Paris (2015), and the Monsoons and ITCZ workshop at Columbia University (2015). The results have been also presented during the AGU Fall meetings in San Francisco (2015, 2016), Ocean Sciences in New Orleans (2016), and PAGES Open Science meeting in Zaragoza (2017).

The project provided interdisciplinary training for three postdoctoral associates (Drs. Natalie Burls, Les Muir and Matthew Thomas), and a Ph.D. student (Georgy Manucharyan). A female early career scientist, Dr. Burls is now an Assistant Professor at George Mason University. Dr. Manucharyan is a Postdoctoral Fellow at Caltech. The project also enhanced and helped maintain the capacity for global climate modeling and analysis by graduate and undergraduate students at Yale University.
